{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:12:47.360
    | text      = Yeah, but I just think that him un-focusing from the people affected and turning it into a larger conspiracy or dismissing it out of hand
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:12:58.320
    | text      = is a great disservice.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:12:59.879
    | text      = You can't open with, okay, sure there are a lot of acres that are burned, sure people have died and property is damaged, yada, yada, yada.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:13:11.559
    | text      = This is about Obama and taxes. Fuck you. Fuck you.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:13:15.960
    | text      = Even if it was about Obama and taxes, there's still people burning.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:13:20.240
    | text      = Right, so Alex is not totally incorrect in his statement that fires have always been a part of Australia.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:13:25.759
    | text      = The continent has a long history of bushfires which have on occasion gotten out of control and caused some severe damage.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:13:31.639
    | text      = Black Saturday in February 2009 is considered the worst fire in recorded Australian history, killing 175 people and destroying more than 2,000 homes.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:13:41.360
    | text      = At this point, the current fires in Australia have killed 27 people, but some estimates of it already destroying more property than the worst bushfire on the books.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:13:51.159
    | text      = Already millions of acres of land is burned and the impact on things like the environment and animal populations, that isn't something we can even really quantify at this point.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:14:00.360
    | text      = Put simply, even though Australia has a history of fires, that is absolutely no excuse not to take what's unfolding right now deathly serious.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:14:08.360
    | text      = First things first, no one is saying that climate change is causing the fires. That is a straw man.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:14:15.360
    | text      = The argument that experts are putting forth is that the effects of climate change are intensifying these fires.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:14:21.360
    | text      = Phys.org spoke with Stanford University environmental studies director Chris Field, who explained the connection between climate change and these fires.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:14:30.360
    | text      = Coincidentally, he also described the fires as, quote, one of the worst, if not the worst climate change extreme events he's ever seen.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:14:37.360
    | text      = What's happened is that Australia has seen decreased rainfall in recent years, while the summer has brought record-setting high temperatures.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:14:46.360
    | text      = These drought conditions create drier fuel for fires, which can be started by accident or by a lightning strike, at which point the fires that are started are far more intense and spread much easier than they would have under different conditions.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:14:59.360
    | text      = 2019 was the hottest and driest year on record for Australia, according to their Bureau of Meteorology, which puts these pieces in place for what we're seeing now.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:15:08.360
    | text      = There's not a lot of mystery about this in the expert community, but somehow to Alex, discussing the impact that climate change has on making these climate events more severe is somehow proof of a grand conspiracy, which is nonsense.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:15:21.360
    | text      = Alex always makes climate change into a conspiracy about people like Obama and Al Gore trying to make money off carbon taxes, but now that I actually think about it, I'm not sure I've ever heard him actually lay out what their profit strategy would be.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:15:34.360
    | text      = I realize that I've always just heard him say that, and like, huh.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:15:39.360
    | text      = Don't worry about it. They're exchanging climate bucks for coal bucks, and that's how they make money, Dan. It makes perfect sense.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:15:48.360
    | text      = But here's the thing. I know he says that they own carbon exchanges, which isn't true, but even if they did, I'm not positive how that would make them rich if there were carbon taxes implemented, because in that framework, the money collected would go to the government.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:16:01.360
    | text      = I think that Alex is mixing up two different potential plans that have been floated about reducing carbon emissions, carbon taxes and cap and trade.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:16:10.360
    | text      = Carbon taxes would just be taxes that polluting businesses would have to pay to the government based on their level of carbon emission. The working theory for this is that there's a burden that the larger population takes on that's caused by the pollution,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:16:23.360
    | text      = so the taxes would be the polluter's way of paying to help mitigate the damage done to everyone. There are people with different views on how that tax money would be spent.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:16:31.360
    | text      = Some people think it should go to subsidized alternative energy sources. Some think it should be paid to the citizens in the form of a carbon dividend. Others advocate it being used for more general infrastructure improvements to make society more able to deal with the consequences that may come.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:16:47.360
    | text      = But the basic idea is that pollution hurts all of us, so the polluter should have to pay to help the larger society deal with those consequences.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:16:55.360
    | text      = The Independent recently reported on a new study conducted by, quote, a coalition of 15 health and environmental organizations, and this report found that your risk of lung cancer rises approximately 10% if you live within 50 meters of a major road,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:17:10.359
    | text      = and that there were additional risks to childhood lung development from the air pollution of living near high levels of traffic.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:17:17.359
    | text      = This is why emissions-restricting regulations are important for the automobile industry, which incidentally is something that Trump has been signaling that he wants to relax considerably.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:17:26.359
    | text      = These are the sorts of things where there is a damage to society, therefore we need to do these things in order to help mitigate that damage.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:17:34.359
    | text      = Or, how about this, all those people can die and they'll get all the profits because fuck them, hooray!
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:17:41.359
    | text      = Right, so that's the working theory behind the carbon taxes idea. Conversely, cap and trade involves the government setting a cap on emissions, which each company could theoretically hit.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:17:50.359
    | text      = But let's say you're running a factory and you make improvements that'll assure that you don't end up hitting that cap.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:17:55.359
    | text      = In that situation, you could sell those permitted emissions to another factory that's going to end up exceeding the cap.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:01.359
    | text      = This system would set an overall ceiling for emissions and make it so that limit is not exceeded.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:07.359
    | text      = Currently, nine states in the United States and many countries around the world have cap and trade systems in place.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:12.359
    | text      = Now granted, there are other cap and trade models that don't have an overall ceiling.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:17.359
    | text      = That ceiling is sort of variable, but the premise is largely that you would have a ceiling and then of those available allowances, people could trade them.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:27.359
    | text      = Right, and if you want any idea of which one would be better for the environment, currently most of these companies are lobbying more for a cap and trade since they assume something is coming.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:40.359
    | text      = So they're putting their money behind cap and trade over carbon tax and I think we all know why.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:47.359
    | text      = They will both do good though, don't get me wrong there.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:50.359
    | text      = I think a lot of the people who make the most sense that I've heard from seem to indicate a mixture of both is probably the best path forward.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:18:59.359
    | text      = Absolutely.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:19:00.359
    | text      = These are two different plans. In the tax model, the amount of carbon emissions would fluctuate, whereas the price of emissions would be static.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:19:08.359
    | text      = Conversely, in the cap and trade model, the market would determine the price businesses would pay to buy or sell carbon allowances, whereas the amount of emissions would be static.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:19:17.359
    | text      = These are intrinsically different but not mutually exclusive and like I said, a lot of experts advocate using both systems in some form.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:19:24.359
    | text      = I'm all about throwing the kitchen sink at it at this point.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:19:26.359
    | text      = Cap and trade is the system wherein Alex's theory of carbon exchanges would be more relevant since I presume that when he's talking about Obama and Al Gore owning these carbon equivalents of stock markets, that's where they would make a cut off the trading of carbon credits.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:19:40.359
    | text      = But Alex never talks about cap and trade. He always talks about carbon taxes, which I find weird since under the plan involving just carbon taxes, that wouldn't necessarily involve exchanges where people are trading emissions as a commodity.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:19:53.359
    | text      = Whenever Alex talks about Al Gore and all of these people owning climate exchanges, he always talks about the Chicago climate exchange like he did in that last clip.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:20:01.359
    | text      = This is probably because Al Gore had invested in that exchange through his generation investment fund, management fund.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:20:08.359
    | text      = However, what Alex fails to mention ever is that the Chicago climate exchange stopped trading in carbon credits in November 2010.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = I'm persecuted for supporting Trump.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:19.359
    | text      = I'm attacked.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:20.359
    | text      = They're trying to shut us down because he's a nationalist.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:22.359
    | text      = He's pro-gun.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:24.359
    | text      = He's calling the shots, not the globalist.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:28.359
    | text      = And so they want to destroy him for wars because they see it as a focal point of Trump's base.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:32.359
    | text      = So fuck the end of that.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:33.359
    | text      = But at the beginning, I think he's on the right track.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:36.359
    | text      = He's on the right side of the idea that Trump would want to extort Iraq before removing troops.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:42.359
    | text      = Yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:43.359
    | text      = Yeah, that is bad.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:44.359
    | text      = The reason I don't want to give him too much props is because I feel like this is a pretty obvious one.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:48.359
    | text      = But I do think that as we are such a negative show about Alex,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:53.359
    | text      = I think it's pretty important to point out the very rare occasions when he has a decent thought.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:31:58.359
    | text      = Because I do think that treating him as a guy who's always wrong about everything,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:04.359
    | text      = while fairly accurate, isn't really fair.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:07.359
    | text      = And it turns him into a monster as opposed to a human who's a monstrous.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:12.359
    | text      = Yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:13.359
    | text      = I see what you're saying.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:14.359
    | text      = I don't have much interest in doing a podcast about a caricature of somebody.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:19.359
    | text      = You are right that it is a very simple and elemental thought that we shouldn't be running an international protection ring.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:28.359
    | text      = Right.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:29.359
    | text      = It does seem like that's a very simple, we shouldn't just be going around country to country being like,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:35.359
    | text      = hey, it'd be terrible if your government was overthrown.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:37.359
    | text      = I'm just saying, you know, pay us a little bit, we'll get our troops out of there. No big deal.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:41.359
    | text      = Yeah. It seems almost, I mean, you're laughing.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:48.359
    | text      = It seems cartoonishly evil.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:51.359
    | text      = So what's happened here is that in the aftermath of the assassination of Qasem Soleimani,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:32:55.359
    | text      = the Iraqi parliament passed a non-binding resolution to expel our troops from the country.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:00.359
    | text      = They were seeking to cancel Iraq's request for U.S. assistance against ISIS,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:04.359
    | text      = which would invalidate our reason to continue to be there in the country.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:08.359
    | text      = This is one of those consequences to the Soleimani assassination that doesn't seem like...
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:12.359
    | text      = I don't understand. We're America. We don't face consequences, Dan.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:15.359
    | text      = It makes it seem like no one really had a plan for this, which isn't good.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:19.359
    | text      = No one has any fucking clue what's going on. It's kind of amazing.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:23.359
    | text      = So the parliament is just requesting that the government of Iraq do this,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:26.359
    | text      = which would make one think that it's not going to go anywhere except for the fact that the resolution was passed
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:31.359
    | text      = after Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi asked parliament to act to expel foreign troops.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:38.359
    | text      = In response, Trump has threatened to, quote, charge them sanctions like they've never seen before ever.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:43.359
    | text      = What does that even fucking mean?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:45.359
    | text      = It'll make Iranian sanctions look somewhat tame.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:47.359
    | text      = He also said, quote, we have very extraordinarily expensive air base there that's there.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:52.359
    | text      = It costs billions of dollars to build. We're not leaving unless they pay us back for it.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:33:57.359
    | text      = Trump is being a huge asshole and acting in ways that are very unhelpful, so it's good to see that Alex can see that.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:04.359
    | text      = The thing is, though, this isn't really different than how Trump always acts,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:08.360
    | text      = so it's unclear why this time Alex is hedging a little bit.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:11.360
    | text      = I would bet it has something to do with realizing that supporting this kind of shit would probably alienate whatever base Alex has left.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:18.360
    | text      = Those calls he took on Friday were not a good sampling of his audience's temperature,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:23.360
    | text      = and if he realizes, like, okay, this is going to possibly extend, the way Trump is acting tends towards trouble,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:32.360
    | text      = and if I support that, I will lose any of the Ron Paul anti-interventionist types that were my bedrock,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:42.360
    | text      = that were the people who theoretically have been around the longest.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:46.360
    | text      = There's a line that Alex can't cross, and that's probably starting a war.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:51.360
    | text      = It's really frustrating to me that that line is the difference of,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:34:55.360
    | text      = I'm fine with him terrorizing black and brown people here, but not in other countries.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:01.360
    | text      = That's a really fucked up line they live on.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:05.360
    | text      = Well, yeah, I mean, it just goes to show, like, people are different.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:09.360
    | text      = People have different thoughts.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:13.360
    | text      = That is not a priority for him.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:16.360
    | text      = That's fair, that's fair.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:18.360
    | text      = But, I mean, it's a tough realization.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:22.360
    | text      = I don't know.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:24.360
    | text      = I guess they do love war.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:28.360
    | text      = They just don't like the fact that there's an end that isn't, like, we unequivocally won.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:35.360
    | text      = Like, the people who want these kinds of wars, or even who don't want it, who have this anti-interventionist thing,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:42.360
    | text      = it's not because of the war part.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:45.360
    | text      = It's because it's going to cost money and last 20 years, like what we're dealing with now.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:49.360
    | text      = Yeah, perhaps.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:50.360
    | text      = What they would prefer is just, like, we win, so now Iraq is 51st state.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:54.360
    | text      = You know, like, it's over.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:56.360
    | text      = Sure, like Alex's buddy who was franchising America.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:35:59.360
    | text      = Yeah, exactly.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:00.360
    | text      = Yeah, yeah, yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:01.360
    | text      = It's like, hey, all right.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:02.360
    | text      = It's a bad idea.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:03.360
    | text      = Yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:04.360
    | text      = So Alex gets back to the climate issues, and we're going to get more of the Australia nonsense here in a little bit.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:10.360
    | text      = But he's mostly complaining about China.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:13.360
    | text      = And in this clip, he's complaining because, and like I said, I really think that a lot of this has to do with watching the Golden Globes,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:21.360
    | text      = because his way in for a lot of this stuff is complaining about Cate Blanchett and others and their speeches.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:29.360
    | text      = So he's complaining about how Blanchett said, you know, when one country faces a climate crisis, we all are facing that.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:38.360
    | text      = And his rebuttal to that is, what about how China puts a lot of trash into the ocean?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:43.360
    | text      = That is a very grown-up and adult way of dealing with that criticism.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:47.360
    | text      = And I have a little thought on the other side of this clip.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:50.360
    | text      = So Cate Blanchett, another one of these strip readers, these teleprompter readers that everybody worships.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:58.360
    | text      = Boo.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:36:59.360
    | text      = Fuck you.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:00.360
    | text      = So when one country faces a climate disaster, we all face a climate disaster.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:04.360
    | text      = Real quick.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:05.360
    | text      = Script reader.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:06.360
    | text      = I don't think you can insult a professional actress as being a script reader.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:10.360
    | text      = That seems...
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:11.360
    | text      = Especially considering you've been, you've read a script, you idiot.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:15.360
    | text      = Wow.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:16.360
    | text      = So when China, who's responsible for over half the trash in the world they admit dumped in the ocean,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:24.360
    | text      = by those big super ships, garbage ships, haulers, when they go out to the 12-mile line and dump it off your coast,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:36.360
    | text      = that does affect the whole world.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:39.360
    | text      = But you never hear a word from these environmental groups about telling China not to do that.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:43.360
    | text      = Yes, you do.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:44.360
    | text      = Yes, all the time.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:45.360
    | text      = That's what we say all the time.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:46.360
    | text      = All the time.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:47.360
    | text      = So I don't know if his statistics are right because I didn't bother to look into them.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:51.360
    | text      = I'm not sure if they are.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:53.360
    | text      = The pollution is a problem and all that, but you do hear environmental groups talking about that quite regularly.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:37:59.360
    | text      = And also, largely the problem with Alex's point here is that his worldview doesn't have a solution to it,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:05.360
    | text      = but globalization does.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:07.360
    | text      = No.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:08.360
    | text      = He's recognizing the interconnectedness of actions that are taken by other countries and how they affect you.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:14.360
    | text      = Okay, so you're saying that that sovereign nation, which I love that they're a sovereign nation,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:19.360
    | text      = by virtue of what they're doing, is hurting me personally?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:23.360
    | text      = So how do I tell them what to do?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:25.360
    | text      = Well, see, the problem is that you can't do anything inside Alex's framework that's completely nationalist about China polluting.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:34.360
    | text      = There's nothing you can do other than, I guess, start a war with them.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:37.360
    | text      = You could impose sanctions, but I don't know if that's going to work.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:40.360
    | text      = You could cut off trade with them, but Alex isn't dominant to think that that's a viable path.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:45.360
    | text      = So in a globalized framework, there would be international mechanisms in place where the responsibilities that different countries have to each other could be handled.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:38:54.360
    | text      = Things that Alex is passionately against, like the Paris Accords, or even, to some extent, the TPP.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:00.360
    | text      = Sure.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:01.360
    | text      = Those would be moves towards that sort of thing being possible.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:04.360
    | text      = Okay.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:05.360
    | text      = And then, obviously, not talking about a one-world government necessarily, but in terms of international bodies that have enforcement mechanisms in place, you could do that.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:19.360
    | text      = Like, hey, China, you are polluting in ways that are affecting other countries, whether it would end up being a financial punitive thing in order to help the country that's affected clean up from the mess that China's making,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:32.360
    | text      = or some kind of a punitive measure that's taken to make them stop doing that.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:38.360
    | text      = International bodies can do that.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:41.360
    | text      = Nationalist countries independently acting cannot, really.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:46.360
    | text      = No, the only way that one country would be able to do something like that is if it were the entire world, Dan.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:52.360
    | text      = What if we have one, let's not do, let's do one nation.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:39:57.360
    | text      = It's just the entire world.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:00.360
    | text      = We're all nationalists now.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:02.360
    | text      = See? Populism.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:03.360
    | text      = I fixed it.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:04.360
    | text      = We'll see.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:05.360
    | text      = Done.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:06.360
    | text      = The issue, too, is like, okay, Alex could say, well, we, as the United States, could put pressure on China in order to make them stop doing that.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:13.360
    | text      = That's not going to work.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:15.360
    | text      = So, what Alex would then say is like, well, a group of nations, sovereign nations, could get together to put pressure on.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:21.360
    | text      = And you see how that already is stepping down the line towards, eventually, what is the ideal solution?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:27.360
    | text      = One-world government.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:28.360
    | text      = That group of nations, sovereign individual nations, working together is good, but what would be better is if China was also one of those nations.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:37.360
    | text      = I don't understand. What are you doing here?
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:39.360
    | text      = You're slowly making more and more sense and I'm not liking it.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:43.360
    | text      = But that's what Alex should recognize as well.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:46.360
    | text      = Because it's very obviously pointing him, like it's in his face.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:50.360
    | text      = Yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:51.360
    | text      = To where he can't even ignore it.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:52.360
    | text      = Not really.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:53.360
    | text      = No.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:54.360
    | text      = That's why some of his ideas are very dumb.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:40:55.360
    | text      = It is. It used to work, but now the world is, when the world was big, nations seemed like you could exist solo.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:41:03.360
    | text      = Yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:41:04.360
    | text      = And now the world is very, very small.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:41:05.360
    | text      = There's far too much interconnectedness for us all to ever really, and we know a lot more than we used to.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:41:11.360
    | text      = Yeah, absolutely.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:41:12.360
    | text      = About the ways that, let's say, air pollution in the, like, let's say, most northern parts of America can affect Canada.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:41:21.360
    | text      = Yeah.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:41:22.360
    | text      = You know, the arbitrary lines of borders don't stop real things.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:41:30.360
    | text      = Yeah.

    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:21.360

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:28.360

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:32.360

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:36.360
    | text      = So I guess it's not just a China thing.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:38.360
    | text      = And it was only 1969 when the Cuyahoga River in Cleveland set on fire here in the United
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:43.360
    | text      = States, and that's not so long ago in the big picture of things.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:47.360

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:51.360
    | text      = And in 1968, the Buffalo River set on fire.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:54.360
    | text      = This would still be happening regularly in the United States if it weren't for the Environmental
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:58.360
    | text      = Protection Agency, which Alex is not a fan of, weirdly.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:02.360
    | text      = Yes, exactly.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:04.360
    | text      = David Sandilow of the Columbia University Center for Global Energy Policy released a
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:11.360
    | text      = 169-page guide to the Chinese climate policy just recently.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:15.360
    | text      = It was reflecting the state of affairs in 2019, as well as initiatives the Chinese government
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:20.360
    | text      = has undertaken to counter climate change.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:22.360
    | text      = Suffice it to say, they just got catalytic converters is not the conclusion this paper
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:28.360
    | text      = arrives at.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:29.360
    | text      = One thing that's important to remember is that China is a massive country and one that
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:33.360
    | text      = has been experiencing a boom in the past decade or so.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:36.360
    | text      = When you talk about one aspect of their energy policy, it's crucial to consider other aspects
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:41.360
    | text      = as well so you can get a full picture.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:43.360
    | text      = For instance, China has added a lot of coal-fired power capacity in the past years.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:48.360
    | text      = But at the same time, they also added, quote, 43% of the world's new renewable power capacity
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:54.360
    | text      = in 2018.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:55.360
    | text      = China is also a country that has 45% of the electric vehicles in the world and 99% of
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:01.360
    | text      = the electric buses in the world.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:03.360
    | text      = Another aspect of this that has to be taken into account is China's gigantic population.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:08.360
    | text      = In 2018, they were the largest emitter of heat-trapping gases.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:12.360
    | text      = But if you look at the numbers on a per capita level, they were only emitting 6.6 metric
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:17.360
    | text      = tons per person as opposed to 15.7 metric tons per American.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:22.360
    | text      = What I'm saying is that there's a complex picture to China and climate issues that's
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:26.360
    | text      = not easily captured by single stats or vague notions like Alex tries to put forth.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:31.360
    | text      = It's probably true that China had previously taken a really dismissive posture towards
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:35.360
    | text      = climate issues, but they've been a bit more responsive in recent years.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:39.360
    | text      = They've announced a plan to achieve peak CO2 emissions by 2030 with goals to hit that
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:44.360
    | text      = peak sooner, a goal that most analysts think is very achievable.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:48.360
    | text      = They've committed to creating 4.5 billion cubic acres of reforestation by 2030, and
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:54.360
    | text      = they actually accomplished that goal 11 years ahead of schedule.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:58.360
    | text      = There are domestic programs in place working in the right direction.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:02.360
    | text      = In their five-year plan covering 2016 to 2020, they put in place regulations that require
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:07.360
    | text      = quote, all new coal plants must use supercritical or ultra-supercritical technology,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:13.360
    | text      = and that older technologies were to be retired.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:16.360
    | text      = By 2017, 90 of their 100 largest coal-burning power plants were ultra-supercritical.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:22.360
    | text      = They launched carbon trading programs in eight cities and provinces with plans to
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:27.360
    | text      = implement it nationally in the near future.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:29.360
    | text      = That is quite literally China placing a price on emitting carbon, which Alex is claiming
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:34.360
    | text      = they refuse to do because they don't want to be competitive, or they don't want to be
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:37.360
    | text      = uncompetitive, excuse me.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:39.360
    | text      = Additionally, they put in place new building standards to make residential and public
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:42.360
    | text      = buildings more energy-efficient, and quote, as of September 2016, roughly 4,500 buildings
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:48.360
    | text      = in China had received green building labels.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:51.360
    | text      = I could go on and on about this stuff, but I think the point is pretty clear.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:54.360
    | text      = It's just not fair to say that China is not doing anything about climate issues.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:58.360
    | text      = The primary conclusion of this report is literally quote, the Chinese government is taking
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:03.360
    | text      = significant steps to address climate change.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:06.360
    | text      = There are negatives in the mix too, like their use of synthetic natural gases, which is not
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:10.360
    | text      = good, but the general trend seems to be in a positive direction.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:14.360
    | text      = China knows that they are a country that's particularly vulnerable to the effects of
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:18.360
    | text      = climate change, from their long history of severe droughts to the more recent phenomenon
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:24.360
    | text      = of horrible air pollution.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:26.360
    | text      = Nothing that Alex is saying at all depicts reality, but I think it might depict reality
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:30.360
    | text      = a little bit closer to the truth.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:33.360
    | text      = The last time he actually cared about doing his job, which would have been in the early
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = to mid 2000s, maybe even longer.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:47:41.360
    | text      = I think this is all just remnants of a time when he actually cared to look into things,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

    | text      = and he just remembers this stuff and hasn't ever checked to update it.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:48:41.360

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:48:42.360
    | text      = And to be totally fair, none of this is to say that the Chinese government is doing everything

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

{{TranscriptBlock

    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:21.360

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:26.360

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:32.360
    | text      = That's just not true.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:34.360
    | text      = Yeah, there is something of a benefit to having a nationalized energy policy that can be enacted
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:42.360
    | text      = with... I mean, not unilaterally, but very aggressively, and the party's pressure can
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:49.360
    | text      = make it happen a lot quicker than if there's... We need to have a year of debate on this
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:55.360
    | text      = and we need to get lobbyists in.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:49:56.360
    | text      = And that's not to say that that makes that system preferable.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:00.360
    | text      = It is one of the things that that system is capable of doing that ours is simply not.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:04.360

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:07.360

}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:08.360
    | text      = And one of the things that I think was really interesting about reading that climate report
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:12.360
    | text      = from the Columbia Energy Policy Center was that something that they highlighted a bit
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:18.360
    | text      = is how one of the things that China does that's really effective is that they set variable
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:24.360
    | text      = goals for the various provinces and cities depending on what is achievable within those
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:30.360
    | text      = so they make this forward progress within the sectors of the country that that progress
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:50:38.360
    | text      = is appropriate and doable.
}}
